item.title: VoIP Without The Internet
item.description: Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) emerged as an alternative telephone service that utilizes existing broadband connections for both internet and phone services. This allows providers to bypass fees associated with leasing traditional copper phone lines, leading to more attractive bundled packages for customers. Theoretically, the internet’s capacity should easily accommodate low-bandwidth voice data. However, this isn’t always the case in reality. Internet paths, much like highways, can become congested, leading to bandwidth constraints, transmission delays (latency), and dropped data packets, all of which disrupt real-time communication like phone calls.

item.title: XO Offering Ethernet to the World
item.description: Global telecommunications companies now have a unique opportunity: access to 4 million commercial buildings across the U.S. for offering Ethernet services. This is made possible by XO Communications’ new Ethernet Hub service. While this might seem irrelevant to businesses unless they’re looking to cut costs on voice and data services, the potential savings hidden within XO’s recent press release are significant. XO Communications is a competitive carrier, meaning they weren’t part of the traditional Bell Telephone system.

item.title: Why Bandwidth is Cheap Downtown
item.description: Want to increase your business internet speed without breaking the bank? Head downtown! The city center offers more competition and cheaper prices than anywhere else. Can’t relocate for better bandwidth deals? There’s a comparable solution that works for many businesses. Why is bandwidth cheaper downtown when real estate is so expensive? The answer is density. Imagine real estate as a pie: limited supply and high demand for the best slices drive up prices.

item.title: T1 vs SIP For Business Telephone
item.description: Large businesses with high call volumes require different telecommunications solutions compared to small offices. While T1 lines have been the traditional choice, SIP Trunking is emerging as a strong alternative. This article explores the pros and cons of each technology to help businesses make informed decisions. T1 lines were initially developed by telephone companies to connect central offices and handle numerous calls simultaneously. This technology, using T-carrier standards (T1 and T3), enabled high-capacity call transportation.

item.title: Yes, There IS Rural Broadband For Businesses
item.description: Many people are excited about the economic stimulus plan’s promise of expanded rural broadband access. However, you might already be able to get the internet speeds your rural business needs. Most major internet providers have overlooked rural areas, not because rural businesses are less important, but because the cost of installing infrastructure like coaxial cables or fiber optic cables is difficult to recoup when there are fewer customers. This is why cable and DSL internet services are less common in the countryside.
